security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing markdown files with example commands. No executable code, no network calls, no file system access. Contains only educational content about documentation fetching strategies.

content.user_title: Add documentation sources to AI knowledge base
content.value_statement: Users need to discover and configure documentation sources for AI agents. This skill provides knowledge of 20+ documentation platforms, fetching strategies, and framework detection patterns to intelligently select the best approach for each documentation site.
actual_capabilities: Detect 20+ documentation frameworks from config files
Select optimal fetching strategy based on site signals
Configure registry entries for documentation sources
Identify AI-native docs (llms.txt, ai.txt) vs traditional formats
Handle GitHub raw, OpenAPI, sitemap, and browser automation strategies
Map libraries to their official documentation sources
limitations: Provides knowledge only - does not execute fetching actions
Requires user to implement actual fetch commands
Site coverage depends on existing documentation platform support
Configuration requires understanding of registry structure

prompt_templates.title: Add new doc source
prompt_templates.scenario: Adding documentation for a new library
prompt_templates.prompt: Add documentation source for [library] at [url]. Detect the framework and select the best fetch strategy.

prompt_templates.title: Detect framework
prompt_templates.prompt: What framework is used by [docs-site-url]? Check for llms.txt, GitHub repo, and config files.

prompt_templates.title: Choose strategy
prompt_templates.prompt: What is the best strategy for fetching docs from [url]? Check for llms.txt, sitemap, and OpenAPI spec.

prompt_templates.title: Auto-discover sources
prompt_templates.prompt: Auto-discover documentation sources for detected frameworks in my project. Check the registry for missing entries.

output: Framework detected: Prisma uses llms.txt format
Registry entry configured with strategy: llmstxt

best_practices: Check for llms.txt before other strategies - it is optimized for AI consumption
Prefer GitHub raw content over web scraping when repository is available
Use browser automation only when curl returns less than 1KB (JS-rendered sites)
Verify fetch strategy works before adding to registry
anti_patterns: Web crawling without checking for llms.txt first
Using browser automation when curl would work
Skipping GitHub raw access when documentation repo is available

faq.question: Which AI tools support this skill?
faq.answer: Works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. Provides documentation fetching knowledge to any compatible AI assistant.

faq.question: How many platforms are supported?
faq.answer: Supports 20+ frameworks including Docusaurus, MkDocs, Mintlify, Fern, Sphinx, Nextra, Starlight, Antora, and GitBook.

faq.question: What is the priority order for fetch strategies?
faq.answer: Priority: llms.txt (1), GitHub raw (2), OpenAPI (3), sitemap (4), browser crawl (5), web crawl (6).

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill contains only documentation - no code executes, no data leaves your system, no network calls are made.

faq.question: Why does curl return small responses for some sites?
faq.answer: Sites using Next.js, Nuxt, or React SSR return minimal HTML. The full content renders via JavaScript - use browser strategy.

faq.question: How does this compare to manual doc fetching?
faq.answer: Provides decision trees and patterns to avoid trial-and-error. Ensures optimal strategy selection for each documentation platform.
